nodes.label: Pythagorean identity for sine and cosine
nodes.title: The fundamental trigonometric identity stating that the square of cosine of an angle plus the square of sine of the same angle equals one.

nodes.label: Sine rule for triangle side ratios
nodes.title: A formula relating the ratios of the lengths of sides of a triangle to the sines of their opposite angles.

nodes.label: Cosine rule for triangle side lengths
nodes.title: A formula expressing the square of one side of a triangle in terms of the squares of the other two sides and the cosine of the included angle.

nodes.label: Cosine of difference of two angles
nodes.title: An identity expressing cosine of the difference between two angles as a combination of the cosines and sines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Cosine of sum of two angles
nodes.title: An identity expressing cosine of the sum of two angles as a combination of the cosines and sines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Double angle formula for cosine (cos 2A)
nodes.title: Formulas expressing cosine of twice an angle in terms of squares of sine and cosine of the original angle.

nodes.label: Sine of sum of two angles
nodes.title: An identity expressing sine of the sum of two angles as a combination of sines and cosines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Sine of difference of two angles
nodes.title: An identity expressing sine of the difference between two angles as a combination of sines and cosines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Tangent of sum of two angles
nodes.title: An identity expressing tangent of the sum of two angles as a ratio involving tangents of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Tangent of difference of two angles
nodes.title: An identity expressing tangent of the difference between two angles as a ratio involving tangents of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Double angle formula for sine (sin 2A)
nodes.title: A formula expressing sine of twice an angle as twice the product of sine and cosine of the original angle.

nodes.label: Half-angle formula for cosine squared
nodes.title: An identity expressing the square of cosine of an angle as half the sum of one and cosine of twice the angle.

nodes.label: Half-angle formula for sine squared
nodes.title: An identity expressing the square of sine of an angle as half the difference of one and cosine of twice the angle.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A cos B
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of cosines of two angles as the sum of cosines of their sum and difference.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A cos B
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of sine of one angle and cosine of another as the sum of sines of their sum and difference.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A sin B
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of sines of two angles as the difference of cosines of their difference and sum.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A sin B
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of cosine of one angle and sine of another as the difference of sines of their sum and difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for cos A + cos B
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sum of cosines of two angles as twice the product of cosines of half their sum and half their difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for cos A – cos B
nodes.title: An identity expressing the difference of cosines of two angles as negative twice the product of sines of half their sum and half their difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for sin A + sin B
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sum of sines of two angles as twice the product of sine of half their sum and cosine of half their difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for sin A – sin B
nodes.title: An identity expressing the difference of sines of two angles as twice the product of cosine of half their sum and sine of half their difference.

nodes.label: Geometric constructions with straight edge and compass
nodes.title: The process of creating geometric figures using only a straight edge and a compass, following specific rules and procedures.

nodes.label: Dynamic geometry software applications
nodes.title: Using software tools that allow for the manipulation and exploration of geometric constructions and concepts in a dynamic way.

nodes.label: Drawing a circle of given radius
nodes.title: The ability to construct a circle with a specified radius using a compass.

nodes.label: Use of straight edge in geometric diagrams
nodes.title: Applying a straight edge to accurately draw straight lines in geometric figures.

nodes.label: Use of protractor in geometric diagrams
nodes.title: Utilizing a protractor to measure and draw angles in geometric constructions.

nodes.label: Understanding linear relationships
nodes.title: Recognizing how two variables relate linearly and can be represented in various forms, including tables and graphs.

nodes.label: Slope of a linear graph
nodes.title: The measure of the steepness or incline of a line on a graph, representing the rate of change of the relationship between two variables.

nodes.label: Point of intersection of two linear relationships
nodes.title: The point where two lines on a graph meet, indicating the solution to a system of linear equations.

nodes.label: Application of the Pythagorean theorem
nodes.title: Using the theorem to find the lengths of sides in right-angled triangles based on the relationship between the sides.

nodes.label: Trigonometric ratios in right-angled triangles
nodes.title: The ratios of the lengths of the sides of a right-angled triangle, specifically sine, cosine, and tangent.

nodes.label: Translations in transformation geometry
nodes.title: The process of moving a shape from one location to another without changing its size, shape, or orientation.

nodes.label: Central symmetry in transformations
nodes.title: A type of symmetry where a shape is invariant under rotation about a central point.

nodes.label: Axial symmetry in transformations
nodes.title: A type of symmetry where a shape is invariant when reflected across a line (axis).

nodes.label: Rotations in transformation geometry
nodes.title: The process of turning a shape around a fixed point at a certain angle.

nodes.label: Scale factor in enlargements
nodes.title: The ratio that describes how much a shape is enlarged or reduced in size during a transformation.

nodes.label: Area effect of enlargements
nodes.title: Understanding how the area of a shape changes when it is enlarged or reduced by a scale factor.

nodes.label: Proof by contradiction
nodes.title: A method of proving a statement by assuming the opposite is true and showing that this leads to a contradiction.

nodes.label: Definition of sine and cosine
nodes.title: The definitions of the sine and cosine functions in relation to the angles of a right triangle.

nodes.label: Trigonometric equations
nodes.title: Equations that involve trigonometric functions and require solving for angle measures.

nodes.label: Graphing trigonometric functions
nodes.title: The process of plotting the sine, cosine, and tangent functions on a coordinate plane.

nodes.label: Radian measure of angles
nodes.title: A method of measuring angles based on the radius of a circle, where one radian is the angle subtended at the center of a circle by an arc equal to the radius.

nodes.label: Use of trigonometry to calculate the area of a triangle

nodes.label: Irrational numbers
nodes.title: Numbers that cannot be expressed as a fraction of two integers, having non-repeating, non-terminating decimal expansions.

nodes.label: Complex numbers
nodes.title: Numbers composed of a real part and an imaginary part, typically expressed in the form a + bi.

nodes.label: Division of complex numbers
nodes.title: The process of dividing one complex number by another, often involving conjugation and multiplication to rationalize the denominator.

nodes.label: Equality of complex numbers
nodes.title: Two complex numbers are equal if their real parts are equal and their imaginary parts are equal.

nodes.label: Argand diagram
nodes.title: A graphical representation of complex numbers on a plane, using the horizontal axis for the real part and the vertical axis for the imaginary part.

nodes.label: Modulus of a complex number
nodes.title: The distance of a complex number from the origin in an Argand diagram, calculated as the square root of the sum of the squares of its real and imaginary parts.

nodes.label: Transformations of complex numbers
nodes.title: Operations that alter the position or form of a complex number in the complex plane, such as rotation or dilation.

nodes.label: Conjugate roots theorem
nodes.title: A theorem stating that if a complex number is a root of a polynomial equation with real coefficients, then its conjugate is also a root.

nodes.label: Polar form of a complex number
nodes.title: A representation of a complex number in terms of its modulus and argument, rather than its real and imaginary components.

nodes.label: Products of complex numbers in polar form
nodes.title: The multiplication of two complex numbers when both are in polar form, involving the multiplication of their moduli and the addition of their arguments.

nodes.label: Quotients of complex numbers in polar form
nodes.title: The division of one complex number by another when both are in polar form, involving the division of their moduli and the subtraction of their arguments.

nodes.label: De Moivre’s theorem
nodes.title: A theorem stating that the nth power of a complex number in polar form can be found by raising its modulus to the nth power and multiplying its argument by n.

nodes.label: Applications of de Moivre’s theorem
nodes.title: The use of de Moivre’s theorem in solving complex number problems, such as finding roots of complex numbers.

nodes.label: Addition of Rational Numbers
nodes.title: Performing addition operations with fractions, decimals, and percentages as different representations of rational numbers.

nodes.label: Subtraction of Rational Numbers
nodes.title: Performing subtraction operations with fractions, decimals, and percentages as different representations of rational numbers.

nodes.label: Multiplication of Rational Numbers
nodes.title: Performing multiplication operations with fractions, decimals, and percentages as different representations of rational numbers.

nodes.label: Division of Rational Numbers
nodes.title: Performing division operations with fractions, decimals, and percentages as different representations of rational numbers.

nodes.label: Negative Numbers in Arithmetic
nodes.title: Understanding and applying rules for addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division involving negative numbers in real-life contexts.

nodes.label: Fractional Amount Problems
nodes.title: Solving problems involving fractional amounts using models like diagrams and real-life contexts.

nodes.label: Decomposition in Arithmetic
nodes.title: Using models like decomposition to understand addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division operations with whole numbers.

nodes.label: Commutative, Associative, and Distributive Laws
nodes.title: Investigating and applying properties of arithmetic operations such as commutative, associative, and distributive laws.

nodes.label: Order of Operations with Brackets
nodes.title: Understanding and applying the correct order of operations, including the use of brackets, in arithmetic expressions.

nodes.label: Geometric Construction of Irrational Numbers
nodes.title: Constructing geometric representations of irrational numbers like √2 and √3.

nodes.label: Complex Numbers in Rectangular Form
nodes.title: Working with complex numbers in the form a+ib and illustrating them on an Argand diagram.

nodes.label: Logarithm Rules
nodes.title: Applying rules of logarithms in problem-solving involving multiplication, division, and exponentiation.

nodes.label: Percentage Calculations
nodes.title: Calculating percentages and using the equivalence of fractions, decimals, and percentages for comparisons.

nodes.label: Indices Rules
nodes.title: Applying rules for indices in mathematical operations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

nodes.label: Arithmetic Sequences and Series
nodes.title: Investigating arithmetic sequences, finding sums of arithmetic series, and proving related identities and inequalities.

nodes.label: Error Accumulation and Estimation
nodes.title: Checking results for accuracy, making estimates, calculating percentage error, and justifying approximations in calculations.

nodes.label: Real-World Problem Solving with Arithmetic
nodes.title: Applying arithmetic skills to solve everyday problems related to finance, measurement, and time.

nodes.label: 2D and 3D Geometry Analysis
nodes.title: Analyzing 2D shapes, 3D solids, and their nets to solve problems involving perimeter, surface area, and volume.

nodes.label: Natural numbers
nodes.title: Counting numbers starting from 1, used for counting objects.

nodes.label: Integers
nodes.title: Whole numbers that can be positive, negative, or zero.

nodes.label: Rational numbers
nodes.title: Numbers that can be expressed as a fraction of two integers, where the denominator is not zero.

nodes.label: Real numbers
nodes.title: The set of all rational and irrational numbers.

nodes.label: Imaginary numbers
nodes.title: Numbers that can be written in the form of a real number multiplied by the imaginary unit i, where i is the square root of -1.

nodes.label: Adding complex numbers
nodes.title: The process of adding the real parts and the imaginary parts of two complex numbers separately.

nodes.label: Multiplying complex numbers
nodes.title: The process of multiplying two complex numbers using the distributive property and the fact that i^2 = -1.

nodes.label: Complex conjugate
nodes.title: Given a complex number, its complex conjugate is formed by changing the sign of its imaginary part.

nodes.label: De Moivre's theorem
nodes.title: A formula that connects complex numbers and trigonometry, stating that (cos θ + i sin θ)^n = cos(nθ) + i sin(nθ) for any integer n.

nodes.label: Double angle formula for cosine
nodes.title: An identity that expresses cosine of double an angle as the difference of the squares of sine and cosine of that angle.

nodes.label: Double angle formula for sine
nodes.title: An identity that expresses sine of double an angle as twice the product of sine and cosine of that angle.

nodes.label: Double angle formula for tangent
nodes.title: An identity that expresses tangent of double an angle in terms of the tangent of that angle.

nodes.label: Cosine of double angle in terms of cosine
nodes.title: An identity expressing cosine of double an angle as a function of the cosine of that angle.

nodes.label: Sine of double angle in terms of cosine
nodes.title: An identity expressing sine of double an angle as a function of the cosine of that angle.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product identities for cosine
nodes.title: Formulas that express the sum or difference of two cosines as a product of sines and cosines.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product identities for sine
nodes.title: Formulas that express the sum or difference of two sines as a product of sines and cosines.

nodes.label: Geometric construction with straight edge
nodes.title: The process of creating geometric figures using only a straight edge, without the aid of measurements.

nodes.label: Geometric construction with compass
nodes.title: The technique of drawing arcs and circles with a compass to create geometric figures.

nodes.label: Geometric construction with protractor
nodes.title: Using a protractor to measure and draw angles accurately in geometric constructions.

nodes.label: Geometric construction with ruler
nodes.title: The use of a ruler to measure lengths and create straight lines in geometric constructions.

nodes.label: Geometric construction with set square
nodes.title: The application of a set square to create right angles and parallel lines in geometric constructions.

nodes.label: Circle construction with given radius
nodes.title: The method of drawing a circle with a specified radius using a compass.

nodes.label: Linear relationships in coordinate geometry
nodes.title: The study of relationships between variables that can be represented as straight lines on a graph.

nodes.label: Slope of a line
nodes.title: The measure of the steepness or incline of a line, calculated as the ratio of the vertical change to the horizontal change between two points on the line.

nodes.label: Rate of change in linear relationships
nodes.title: The constant rate at which one variable changes with respect to another in a linear relationship, represented by the slope.

nodes.label: Intersection of linear relationships
nodes.title: The point at which two linear equations intersect, representing a solution to the system of equations.

nodes.label: Pythagorean theorem application
nodes.title: Using the Pythagorean theorem to find the lengths of sides in right-angled triangles based on the relationship a² + b² = c².

nodes.label: Trigonometric ratios
nodes.title: The ratios of the lengths of the sides of a right triangle, specifically sine, cosine, and tangent, used to relate angles to side lengths.

nodes.label: Area of a triangle using trigonometry
nodes.title: Calculating the area of a triangle using the formula A = 1/2 * base * height or using trigonometric ratios.

nodes.label: Sine rule for triangle side lengths
nodes.title: A formula that relates the lengths of the sides of a triangle to the sines of its opposite angles, used for solving non-right triangles.

nodes.label: Enlargement in transformation geometry
nodes.title: A transformation that increases or decreases the size of a shape while maintaining its proportions, defined by a scale factor.

nodes.label: Centre of enlargement
nodes.title: The fixed point in a plane about which a shape is enlarged or reduced during a transformation.

nodes.label: Symmetry in transformations
nodes.title: The property of a shape that remains unchanged under certain transformations, such as translation, rotation, or reflection.

nodes.label: Enlargements
nodes.title: A transformation that changes the size of a geometric figure, characterized by a scale factor relative to a point of enlargement.

nodes.label: Constructions
nodes.title: The process of drawing geometric figures using only a compass and straightedge, based on given conditions.

nodes.label: Antidifferentiation
nodes.title: The reverse process of differentiation, finding a function whose derivative is the given function.

nodes.label: Integrating exponential functions
nodes.title: The process of finding the integral of functions involving the exponential function, typically involving a base of e.

nodes.label: Integrating trigonometric functions
nodes.title: The process of finding the integral of trigonometric functions, such as sine, cosine, and tangent.

nodes.label: Applications of integration
nodes.title: Using integration to solve real-world problems, such as calculating areas under curves and volumes of solids of revolution.

nodes.label: Definite integrals
nodes.title: The calculation of the integral of a function with specified upper and lower limits, representing the area under the curve between these two points.

nodes.label: Finding areas by integration
nodes.title: Determining the area under a curve or between curves by evaluating the definite integral of a function over a specified interval.

nodes.label: Average value of a function
nodes.title: The average value of a continuous function over a given interval, calculated as the integral of the function over the interval divided by the length of the interval.

nodes.label: Addition of Natural Numbers
nodes.title: The process of combining natural numbers to find the total sum.

nodes.label: Addition of Integers
nodes.title: The process of adding positive and negative whole numbers together.

nodes.label: Subtraction of Natural Numbers
nodes.title: The process of finding the difference between two natural numbers.

nodes.label: Subtraction of Integers
nodes.title: The process of subtracting positive and negative whole numbers.

nodes.label: Multiplication of Natural Numbers
nodes.title: The process of repeated addition to find the total product.

nodes.label: Multiplication of Integers
nodes.title: The process of multiplying positive and negative whole numbers.

nodes.label: Division of Natural Numbers
nodes.title: The process of sharing or grouping natural numbers to find the quotient.

nodes.label: Division of Integers
nodes.title: The process of dividing positive and negative whole numbers.

nodes.label: Order of Operations
nodes.title: Rules that dictate the sequence in which mathematical operations should be performed.

nodes.label: Properties of Arithmetic
nodes.title: Rules and relationships that govern arithmetic operations such as commutative, associative, and distributive laws.

nodes.label: Fraction Operations
nodes.title: Performing arithmetic operations on fractions including addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

nodes.label: Decimal Operations
nodes.title: Performing arithmetic operations on decimals including addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

nodes.label: Square roots of negative numbers
nodes.title: The operation of finding a number which, when multiplied by itself, results in a negative number, represented in the form of imaginary numbers.

nodes.label: Surds
nodes.title: An expression containing a square root, cube root, etc., that cannot be simplified to remove the root.

nodes.label: Partitioned set of Real numbers
nodes.title: The classification of real numbers into subsets such as natural numbers, integers, rational numbers, and irrational numbers, with no overlap between the sets.

nodes.label: Definite integral
nodes.title: A definite integral calculates the area under a curve between two specified points on the x-axis, providing a numerical value for the area.

nodes.label: Indefinite integral
nodes.title: An indefinite integral represents a family of functions and includes a constant of integration, indicating the general form of antiderivatives.

nodes.label: Limits of integration
nodes.title: The limits of integration are the specific values that define the interval over which a definite integral is evaluated, typically denoted as 'a' and 'b'.

nodes.label: Constant of integration
nodes.title: The constant of integration is an arbitrary constant added to the result of an indefinite integral, representing the family of antiderivatives.

nodes.label: Area under a curve
nodes.title: The area under a curve is calculated using definite integrals and represents the total area between the curve and the x-axis over a specified interval.

nodes.label: Slope of a tangent
nodes.title: The slope of a tangent to a curve at a given point is the derivative of the function at that point, representing the instantaneous rate of change.

nodes.label: Stationary points
nodes.title: Stationary points are points on a curve where the derivative is zero, indicating potential local maxima, minima, or points of inflection.

nodes.label: Local maximum point
nodes.title: A local maximum point is a stationary point where the function value is greater than the values of the function in its immediate vicinity.

nodes.label: Local minimum point
nodes.title: A local minimum point is a stationary point where the function value is less than the values of the function in its immediate vicinity.

nodes.label: Point of inflection
nodes.title: A point of inflection is a point on a curve where the concavity changes, which can be identified where the second derivative is zero and changes sign.

nodes.label: Second derivative test
nodes.title: The second derivative test is a method used to determine the nature of stationary points by evaluating the sign of the second derivative at those points.

nodes.label: Rates of change
nodes.title: Rates of change describe how a quantity changes in relation to another quantity, often represented as derivatives in calculus.

nodes.label: Chain rule
nodes.title: The chain rule is a formula for computing the derivative of the composition of two or more functions, allowing for the differentiation of complex functions.

nodes.label: Average value of a function over an interval
nodes.title: The average value of a function over an interval [a, b] is calculated as the integral of the function over that interval divided by the length of the interval.

nodes.label: Geometric series
nodes.title: A geometric series is a series of terms where each term after the first is found by multiplying the previous term by a fixed, non-zero number called the common ratio.

nodes.label: Compound interest formula
nodes.title: The compound interest formula calculates the total amount of money accumulated after n years, including interest on both the initial principal and the accumulated interest.

nodes.label: Present value
nodes.title: Present value is the current worth of a future sum of money or stream of cash flows given a specified rate of return.

nodes.label: Future value
nodes.title: Future value is the amount of money that an investment made today will grow to at a specified interest rate over a specified period of time.

nodes.label: Straight line depreciation
nodes.title: Straight line depreciation is a method of allocating the cost of a tangible asset over its useful life, where the asset loses value by a constant amount each year.

nodes.label: Reducing balance depreciation
nodes.title: Reducing balance depreciation is a method where the asset loses value by a fixed percentage of its remaining book value each year.

nodes.label: Instalment savings
nodes.title: Instalment savings involve regularly saving a fixed amount of money over a period of time, where each payment earns compound interest based on the time it is invested.

nodes.label: Probability distribution
nodes.title: A probability distribution describes how the probabilities are distributed over the values of the random variable, indicating the likelihood of each outcome.

nodes.label: Expected value
nodes.title: Expected value is the average of all possible outcomes of a random variable, weighted by their probabilities, providing a measure of the center of the distribution.

nodes.label: Tree diagram
nodes.title: A tree diagram is a graphical representation of all possible outcomes of an event, where each branch represents a possible outcome and its associated probability.

nodes.label: Measurement accuracy tolerance
nodes.title: The acceptable range within which a measurement can vary, typically expressed as a plus or minus value around a central measurement.

nodes.label: Decimal place accuracy
nodes.title: Refers to the precision of a measurement expressed to a specific number of decimal places, impacting the minimum and maximum possible values.

nodes.label: Relative error
nodes.title: The ratio of the absolute error to the true value, often expressed as a fraction or percentage, indicating the size of the error in relation to the actual measurement.

nodes.label: Percentage error
nodes.title: The relative error expressed as a percentage, calculated by dividing the absolute error by the true value and multiplying by 100.

nodes.label: Trapezoidal rule for area calculation
nodes.title: A numerical method for estimating the area under a curve by dividing it into trapezoids and summing their areas.

nodes.label: Ordinates in trapezoidal rule
nodes.title: The heights measured at specific intervals used to form the bases of trapezoids in the trapezoidal rule for area estimation.

nodes.label: Approximate area calculation
nodes.title: The process of estimating the area under a curve using methods like the trapezoidal rule, which provides an approximation rather than an exact value.

nodes.label: Tree diagram for probability
nodes.title: A visual representation of all possible outcomes of a probabilistic experiment, where each branch represents a possible outcome.

nodes.label: Discrete random variable
nodes.title: A type of random variable that can take on a countable number of distinct values, often used in probability distributions.

nodes.label: Continuous random variable
nodes.title: A random variable that can take on any value within a given range, often associated with measurements.

nodes.label: Bernoulli trial
nodes.title: A random experiment with exactly two possible outcomes, often referred to as success and failure.

nodes.label: Binomial distribution
nodes.title: A probability distribution that summarizes the number of successes in a fixed number of independent Bernoulli trials.

nodes.label: Multiplication rule for independent events
nodes.title: A rule stating that the probability of two independent events occurring together is the product of their individual probabilities.

nodes.label: Conditional probability
nodes.title: The probability of an event occurring given that another event has already occurred.

nodes.label: Permutations
nodes.title: An arrangement of objects in a specific order, where the order of selection matters.

nodes.label: Combinations
nodes.title: A selection of objects where the order of selection does not matter.

nodes.label: Scatter diagram
nodes.title: A graph that displays values for two variables, showing the relationship between them through plotted points.

nodes.label: Correlation
nodes.title: A statistical measure that describes the extent to which two variables change together, indicating the strength and direction of their relationship.

nodes.label: Line of best fit
nodes.title: A straight line that best represents the data on a scatter plot, used to predict values and analyze relationships.

nodes.label: Domain and Range
nodes.title: Domain is the set of all possible input values, and range is the set of all possible output values of a function.

nodes.title: Functions involving logarithms, which are the inverses of exponential functions.

nodes.title: States that the sampling distribution of the sample mean approximates a normal distribution as sample size increases.

nodes.label: null hypothesis formulation
nodes.title: The process of stating the null hypothesis (H0), which is a default assumption that there is no effect or difference in a statistical test.

nodes.label: alternative hypothesis formulation
nodes.title: The process of stating the alternative hypothesis (H1), which represents the claim or effect that is tested against the null hypothesis.

nodes.label: significance level specification
nodes.title: Choosing the significance level (alpha), typically 0.05, which is the threshold probability for rejecting the null hypothesis in a statistical test.

nodes.label: test statistic calculation
nodes.title: Computing the test statistic, a numerical value derived from sample data used to determine whether to reject the null hypothesis.

nodes.label: p-value determination
nodes.title: Finding the p-value, which is the probability of obtaining a test statistic at least as extreme as the one observed, assuming the null hypothesis is true.

nodes.label: hypothesis test decision rule based on p-value
nodes.title: The rule that if the p-value is less than or equal to the significance level, reject the null hypothesis; otherwise, do not reject it.

nodes.label: Polynomial expression
nodes.title: An expression formed from the addition of algebraic terms with positive integer powers, such as 5x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 6.

nodes.label: Degree of a polynomial
nodes.title: The degree of a polynomial is the highest power of the variable in the expression.

nodes.label: Linear polynomial
nodes.title: A polynomial of degree 1, such as 4x - 6.

nodes.label: Quadratic polynomial
nodes.title: A polynomial of degree 2, such as -3x^2 + 4x - 6.

nodes.label: Cubic polynomial
nodes.title: A polynomial of degree 3, such as 5x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 6.

nodes.label: Combining like terms
nodes.title: The process of simplifying a polynomial by adding or subtracting coefficients of terms with the same variable and power.

nodes.label: Binomial expression
nodes.title: An expression that contains exactly two terms, such as x + y.

nodes.label: Trinomial expression
nodes.title: An expression that contains exactly three terms, such as x^2 + 5x + 6.

nodes.label: Distributive law
nodes.title: A property that states a(b + c) = ab + ac, used for multiplying expressions.

nodes.label: Multiplying polynomial expressions
nodes.title: The process of using the distributive law to multiply polynomials, often referred to as expanding.

nodes.label: Perfect square polynomial
nodes.title: A polynomial that can be expressed in the form (x - a)^2, resulting in x^2 - 2ax + a^2.

nodes.label: Difference of two squares
nodes.title: An expression of the form a^2 - b^2, which can be factored into (a - b)(a + b).

nodes.label: Dividing algebraic expressions
nodes.title: The process of simplifying a fraction where the numerator and denominator are polynomials.

nodes.label: Finding the highest common factor
nodes.title: The process of identifying the largest polynomial that divides two or more polynomials without leaving a remainder.

nodes.label: Factoring quadratic expressions
nodes.title: The process of expressing a quadratic polynomial in the form (x - p)(x - q), where p and q are the roots.

nodes.label: Quadratic formula
nodes.title: A formula used to find the roots of a quadratic equation, given by x = (-b ± √(b² - 4ac)) / (2a).

nodes.label: Evaluating polynomial functions
nodes.title: The process of substituting a specific value for the variable in a polynomial function to find the corresponding output.

nodes.label: Roots of an equation
nodes.title: The values of the variable that satisfy the equation, making it equal to zero.

nodes.label: Simultaneous linear equations
nodes.title: A set of equations with multiple variables that are solved together to find a common solution.

nodes.label: Graphing quadratic functions
nodes.title: The process of plotting the graph of a quadratic function, which typically produces a parabolic shape.

nodes.label: Completing the square
nodes.title: A method used to convert a quadratic expression into a perfect square trinomial, facilitating the solving of quadratic equations.

nodes.label: Discriminant of a quadratic equation
nodes.title: The expression b² - 4ac in the quadratic formula, which determines the nature of the roots (real and distinct, real and equal, or complex).

nodes.label: Rational roots
nodes.title: Roots of a polynomial equation that can be expressed as a fraction, occurring when the discriminant is a perfect square.

nodes.label: Factor theorem
nodes.title: A theorem stating that if f(k) = 0 for a polynomial f(x), then (x - k) is a factor of f(x).

nodes.label: Graphing cubic functions
nodes.title: The process of plotting the graph of a cubic function, which can have various shapes depending on the coefficients.

nodes.label: Rationalising the denominator
nodes.title: The process of eliminating a surd from the denominator of a fraction by multiplying by a suitable form of 1.

nodes.label: Quadratic equations
nodes.title: Concept referenced in relationship: Quadratic equations

nodes.label: Factorising algebraic expressions
nodes.title: Concept referenced in relationship: Factorising algebraic expressions

nodes.label: Nature of quadratic roots
nodes.title: Concept referenced in relationship: Nature of quadratic roots

nodes.label: Graph of a quadratic function
nodes.title: A visual representation of a quadratic function, typically showing a parabolic shape.

nodes.label: Vertex of a parabola
nodes.title: The highest or lowest point on the graph of a quadratic function, representing the maximum or minimum value of the function.

nodes.label: Coefficient factoring out
nodes.title: The process of factoring out the greatest common coefficient of a quadratic expression to simplify the expression or solve the equation.

nodes.label: Minimum point of a parabola
nodes.title: The lowest point on the graph of a quadratic function, occurring when the parabola opens upwards.

nodes.label: Maximum point of a parabola
nodes.title: The highest point on the graph of a quadratic function, occurring when the parabola opens downwards.

nodes.label: Axis of symmetry of a parabola
nodes.title: A vertical line that divides the parabola into two mirror-image halves, passing through the vertex of the parabola.

nodes.label: Surd
nodes.title: An expression involving square roots that cannot be simplified into a rational number.

nodes.label: Rationalizing the denominator
nodes.title: The process of eliminating surds from the denominator of a fraction by multiplying the numerator and the denominator by an appropriate expression.

nodes.label: Sine rule
nodes.title: A formula relating the lengths of sides of a triangle to the sines of its angles, used to solve for unknown sides or angles in non-right-angled triangles.

nodes.label: Cosine rule
nodes.title: A formula used to calculate the length of a side of a triangle when the lengths of the other two sides and the included angle are known, or to find the size of an angle when the lengths of all three sides are known.

nodes.label: Radian measure
nodes.title: A unit of angular measure used in mathematics, where one radian is the angle subtended at the center of a circle by an arc whose length is equal to the radius of the circle.

nodes.label: Arc length
nodes.title: The distance measured along the path of a circular arc.

nodes.label: Area of a sector
nodes.title: The area enclosed by two radii of a circle and the arc between them, calculated as a fraction of the circle's total area based on the angle at the center.

nodes.label: Finding angles in triangles
nodes.title: Concept referenced in relationship: Finding angles in triangles

nodes.label: Understanding periodicity
nodes.title: Concept referenced in relationship: Understanding periodicity

nodes.label: Parallel lines equal slopes
nodes.title: Parallel lines in a plane have the same slope, indicating they will never intersect.

nodes.label: Area of a triangle using vertices
nodes.title: The area of a triangle can be calculated using the coordinates of its vertices with a specific formula.

nodes.label: Translation of triangle vertices
nodes.title: A translation in geometry involves moving every point of a shape the same distance in the same direction, applied here to the vertices of a triangle.

nodes.label: General form of the equation of a line
nodes.title: The general form of the equation of a line is ax + by + c = 0, where a, b, and c are constants.

nodes.label: Slope-intercept form of the equation of a line
nodes.title: The slope-intercept form of a line's equation is y = mx + c, where m is the slope and c is the y-intercept.

nodes.label: Collinear points
nodes.title: Points that lie on the same straight line are described as collinear.

nodes.label: Slope as tangent of angle with x-axis
nodes.title: The slope of a line is defined as the tangent of the angle which the line makes with the positive direction of the x-axis.

nodes.label: Equation of a line given point and slope
nodes.title: The equation of a line can be found using the slope of the line and a point on the line, using the formula y - y1 = m(x - x1).

nodes.label: Perpendicular distance from a point to a line
nodes.title: The perpendicular distance from a point to a line is the shortest distance from the point to any point on the line.

nodes.label: Angle between two lines
nodes.title: The angle between two lines is found using the slopes of the lines and the formula involving the tangent of the angle.

nodes.label: Fundamental principle of counting
nodes.title: The principle that if one task can be done in m ways and another independent task can be done in n ways, then both tasks can be done in m * n ways.

nodes.label: Factorial notation
nodes.title: Factorial notation (n!) represents the product of all positive integers up to n.

nodes.label: Mutually exclusive events
nodes.title: Two events are mutually exclusive if the occurrence of one event means the other cannot occur at the same time.

nodes.label: Experimental probability
nodes.title: Experimental probability is an estimate of the likelihood of an event occurring, based on the number of times the event occurs in a given number of trials.

nodes.label: Expected frequency
nodes.title: Expected frequency is the predicted number of times an event will occur in a series of trials, based on the probability of the event.

nodes.label: Independent events
nodes.title: Two events are independent if the occurrence of one event does not affect the probability of the other event occurring.

nodes.label: Sample space
nodes.title: Concept referenced in relationship: Sample space

nodes.label: The General Multiplication Law
nodes.title: Concept referenced in relationship: The General Multiplication Law

nodes.label: Average rate of change
nodes.title: Concept referenced in relationship: Average rate of change

nodes.label: Ratio of segments divided by a line parallel to a triangle side
nodes.title: A theorem stating that a line drawn parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two sides in the same ratio.

nodes.label: Proportional sides of similar triangles
nodes.title: If two triangles are similar, their corresponding sides are proportional to each other.

nodes.label: Angle subtended at the center of a circle
nodes.title: The angle formed at the center of a circle by two radii extending to the endpoints of an arc is twice the angle subtended at the circumference by the same arc.

nodes.label: Angles at the circumference on the same arc
nodes.title: Angles subtended at the circumference of a circle by the same arc are equal.

nodes.label: Perpendicular from center to a chord bisects the chord
nodes.title: The perpendicular line drawn from the center of a circle to a chord bisects that chord.

nodes.label: Tangent to a circle
nodes.title: A tangent is a line that touches a circle at exactly one point, forming a right angle with the radius at that point.

nodes.label: Limit of a function
nodes.title: The limit of a function describes the value that a function approaches as the input approaches a certain point.

nodes.label: Instantaneous rate of change
nodes.title: The instantaneous rate of change of a function at a point is the slope of the tangent line to the curve at that point.

nodes.label: Derivative of a function
nodes.title: The derivative of a function represents the rate at which the function's value changes with respect to changes in its input.

nodes.label: Product rule for differentiation
nodes.title: The product rule states that the derivative of a product of two functions is the first function times the derivative of the second plus the second function times the derivative of the first.

nodes.label: Quotient rule for differentiation
nodes.title: The quotient rule states that the derivative of a quotient of two functions is the bottom function times the derivative of the top minus the top function times the derivative of the bottom, all divided by the square of the bottom function.

nodes.label: Chain rule for differentiation
nodes.title: The chain rule states that to differentiate a composite function, you take the derivative of the outer function and multiply it by the derivative of the inner function.

nodes.label: Second derivative
nodes.title: The second derivative is the derivative of the derivative of a function, indicating the rate of change of the rate of change.

nodes.label: Standard derivatives of trigonometric functions
nodes.title: The derivatives of the basic trigonometric functions: the derivative of sine is cosine, the derivative of cosine is negative sine, and the derivative of tangent is secant squared.

nodes.label: Differentiation of exponential functions
nodes.title: The derivative of an exponential function is proportional to the function itself, specifically for the base e, the derivative is e^x.

nodes.label: Differentiation of logarithmic functions
nodes.title: The derivative of the natural logarithm function ln(x) is 1/x.

nodes.label: Arithmetic sequence
nodes.title: An arithmetic sequence is a sequence of numbers in which the difference between consecutive terms is constant.

nodes.label: Common difference in arithmetic sequences
nodes.title: The common difference is the fixed amount that each term in an arithmetic sequence increases or decreases by.

nodes.label: Double-angle formula for sine
nodes.title: A trigonometric identity that expresses the sine of twice an angle in terms of the sine and cosine of the angle.

nodes.label: Double-angle formula for cosine
nodes.title: A trigonometric identity that expresses the cosine of twice an angle in terms of the square of the sine and cosine of the angle.

nodes.label: Double-angle formula for tangent
nodes.title: A trigonometric identity that expresses the tangent of twice an angle in terms of the tangent of the angle.

nodes.label: Sum to product formulae
nodes.title: Formulae that convert sums or differences of trigonometric functions into products.

nodes.label: Inverse trigonometric functions
nodes.title: Functions that determine the angle that produces a given trigonometric value.

nodes.label: Arithmetic sequences
nodes.title: Sequences in which each term changes by the same fixed amount from the previous term.

nodes.label: Geometric sequences
nodes.title: Sequences formed when each term of the sequence is obtained by multiplying the previous term by a fixed amount.

nodes.label: Arithmetic series
nodes.title: The sum of the terms of an arithmetic sequence.

nodes.label: Sigma notation
nodes.title: A concise way of representing sums of sequences or series using the Greek letter sigma (Σ).

nodes.label: Limits of sequences
nodes.title: The value that the terms of a sequence approach as the number of terms increases indefinitely.

nodes.label: Simple random sampling
nodes.title: A sampling method where each sample of size n has an equal chance of being selected, ensuring each member of the population has an equal chance of inclusion.

nodes.label: Stratified sampling
nodes.title: A sampling method where the population is divided into distinct subgroups (strata) and random samples are taken from each stratum proportionally.

nodes.label: Systematic sampling
nodes.title: A sampling technique where elements are selected at regular intervals from an ordered list, starting at a random point.

nodes.label: Quota sampling
nodes.title: A non-probability sampling method where the population is divided into groups and samples are taken based on predetermined quotas for each group.

nodes.label: Cluster sampling
nodes.title: A sampling method where the population is divided into clusters, and a random sample of these clusters is selected for study.

nodes.label: Convenience sampling
nodes.title: A non-probability sampling method where samples are selected based on their availability and willingness to participate.

nodes.label: Mode
nodes.title: The value that appears most frequently in a data set.

nodes.label: Mean
nodes.title: The arithmetic average of a set of numbers, found by dividing the sum of the values by the count of numbers.

nodes.label: Median
nodes.title: The middle value in a data set when the values are arranged in ascending or descending order.

nodes.label: Range
nodes.title: The difference between the highest and lowest values in a data set.

nodes.label: Interquartile range
nodes.title: The difference between the upper quartile (Q3) and the lower quartile (Q1) in a data set, representing the spread of the middle 50% of the data.

nodes.label: Standard deviation
nodes.title: A measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values, indicating how much the values deviate from the mean.

nodes.label: Percentiles
nodes.title: Values that divide a data set into 100 equal parts, indicating the percentage of data below a certain value.

nodes.label: Stem and leaf diagram
nodes.title: A graphical method used to display quantitative data where each data value is split into a 'stem' (the leading digit(s)) and a 'leaf' (the final digit).

nodes.label: Histogram
nodes.title: A graphical representation of the distribution of numerical data, where the data is grouped into ranges and each range is represented by a bar.

nodes.label: Skewed distribution
nodes.title: A distribution where the data is not symmetrically distributed, showing a tail that extends more to one side than the other.

nodes.label: Symmetrical distribution
nodes.title: A distribution where the data is evenly distributed around the mean, showing mirror-image sides.

nodes.label: Bimodal distribution
nodes.title: A distribution with two different modes or peaks, indicating two prevalent values in the data set.

nodes.label: Inequality Symbols
nodes.title: Symbols like !, ", #, $ used to represent different types of inequalities in mathematical expressions.

nodes.label: Basic Rules of Inequalities
nodes.title: Rules for adding or subtracting a constant, multiplying or dividing by a positive number, and the reversal of inequality symbol when multiplying or dividing by a negative number.

nodes.label: Combining Inequalities
nodes.title: The process of combining multiple inequalities to determine a solution set that satisfies all given conditions.

nodes.label: Graphical Construction for Inequalities
nodes.title: Using graphs of functions to aid in understanding and solving inequalities.

nodes.label: Rational Inequalities
nodes.title: Inequalities involving rational functions, where the numerator and denominator are polynomials in x.

nodes.label: Modulus Function
nodes.title: A function that returns the positive value of a number, often represented as |x|.

nodes.label: Logarithmic Function
nodes.title: A function that focuses on the index (or exponent) of a number, often written as log_a(x).

nodes.label: Laws of Logarithms
nodes.title: Rules governing the manipulation of logarithmic expressions, including properties like log_a(xy) = log_a(x) + log_a(y).

nodes.label: Exponential Equations
nodes.title: Equations involving exponential functions, often used to model growth or decay.

nodes.label: Proofs by Induction
nodes.title: A method of mathematical proof that establishes a statement for all natural numbers by proving it for a base case and then showing it holds for the next case assuming it holds for the current case.

nodes.title: Concept referenced in relationship: Direct proof

nodes.label: Linear functions graphed as ax+b
nodes.title: Functions represented by straight lines in the form ax + b where a, b are rational numbers.

nodes.label: Composite functions
nodes.title: Functions created by combining two or more functions.

nodes.label: Quadratic functions graphed as ax^2 + bx + c
nodes.title: Functions represented by parabolic curves in the form ax^2 + bx + c where a, b, c are integers.

nodes.label: Cubic functions graphed as ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d
nodes.title: Functions represented by cubic curves in the form ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d where a, b, c, d are integers.

nodes.label: Linear functions graphed as abx
nodes.title: Functions represented by straight lines in the form abx where a is a natural number and b is a real number.

nodes.label: Quadratic functions in complete square form
nodes.title: Quadratic functions expressed as a perfect square trinomial.

nodes.label: Limits of functions
nodes.title: The value that a function approaches as the input approaches a certain value.

nodes.label: Surjective functions
nodes.title: Functions where every element in the codomain is mapped to by at least one element in the domain.

nodes.label: Injective functions
nodes.title: Functions where each element in the domain is mapped to a distinct element in the codomain.

nodes.label: Bijective functions
nodes.title: Functions that are both injective and surjective.

nodes.label: First derivatives of functions
nodes.title: The rate of change of a function at a given point.

nodes.label: Second derivatives of functions
nodes.title: The rate of change of the rate of change of a function at a given point.

nodes.title: Finding the original function from its derivative.

nodes.title: Finding the antiderivative of a function.

nodes.label: Pythagorean Theorem
nodes.title: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the length of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

nodes.label: Circumcircle
nodes.title: The circle passing through all three vertices of a triangle.

nodes.label: Incircle
nodes.title: The circle that is tangent to all three sides of a triangle.

nodes.label: Circumcentre
nodes.title: The centre of the circumcircle of a triangle.

nodes.label: Incentre
nodes.title: The centre of the incircle of a triangle.

nodes.label: Median of a Triangle
nodes.title: A line segment from a vertex of a triangle to the midpoint of the opposite side.

nodes.label: Centroid
nodes.title: The point of concurrency of the medians of a triangle.

nodes.label: Orthocentre

nodes.label: Polynomial expressions
nodes.title: Expressions that involve variables raised to whole number exponents and their coefficients.

nodes.label: Simplifying algebraic fractions
nodes.title: Reducing algebraic fractions to their simplest form by factoring numerators and denominators and cancelling common factors.

nodes.label: Binomial expansions
nodes.title: The process of expanding expressions that are raised to a power, where the expression consists of two terms.

nodes.label: Algebraic identities
nodes.title: Equations that hold true for all values of the variables involved.

nodes.label: Manipulating formulae
nodes.title: The process of rearranging and simplifying formulae to solve for a particular variable.

nodes.label: Algebraic patterns
nodes.title: Identifying and describing patterns and relationships in sequences using algebraic expressions.

nodes.label: Solving equations
nodes.title: The process of finding the values of variables that satisfy an equation.

nodes.label: Solving simultaneous linear equations
nodes.title: Finding the values of variables that satisfy two or more linear equations at the same time.

nodes.label: Solving quadratic and linear equations
nodes.title: The process of finding the solution(s) to quadratic equations and linear equations.

nodes.title: Creating quadratic equations given the solutions or roots of the equation.

nodes.label: Max and min of quadratic graphs
nodes.title: Determining the maximum or minimum points on the graph of a quadratic function.

nodes.label: Algebraic surd equations
nodes.title: Equations involving surds that require algebraic manipulation to solve.

nodes.label: The factor theorem
nodes.title: A theorem stating that a polynomial has a factor if and only if the polynomial evaluates to zero at the value of the variable corresponding to that factor.

nodes.label: Graphs of cubic (and higher order) polynomials
nodes.title: The representation of polynomial functions of degree three or higher on a coordinate plane.

nodes.label: Listing outcomes of experiments
nodes.title: Identifying and writing down all possible results of a specific experiment.

nodes.label: Probability of an event occurring
nodes.title: The likelihood of a specific event happening, ranging from 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain).

nodes.label: Difference between experimental and theoretical probability
nodes.title: The distinction between the probability based on actual outcomes (experimental) and the probability based on calculations or models (theoretical).

nodes.label: Constructing sample spaces for events
nodes.title: Creating a list of all possible outcomes for a specific event or experiment.

nodes.label: Principle of equally likely outcomes
nodes.title: In situations where all outcomes are equally probable, the probability of an event is the ratio of favorable outcomes to total outcomes.

nodes.label: Misuses of statistics
nodes.title: Instances where statistical data is manipulated or misinterpreted to convey misleading information.

nodes.label: Types of data (categorical, numerical)
nodes.title: Data categorized as either categorical (qualitative) or numerical (quantitative) to aid in analysis and interpretation.

nodes.label: Arrangements of distinct objects
nodes.title: Determining the number of ways to order a set of unique objects.

nodes.label: Selecting objects from a set
nodes.title: Choosing a specific number of items from a larger group of distinct objects.

nodes.label: Set theory in probability
nodes.title: Using mathematical sets to analyze and describe the outcomes and events in probability experiments.

nodes.label: Expected value in probability
nodes.title: The anticipated value of an event calculated by multiplying each possible outcome by its probability of occurrence.

nodes.label: Bernoulli trials
nodes.title: A sequence of independent experiments with two possible outcomes, often used in probability theory.

nodes.label: Sampling distributions
nodes.title: The probability distribution of a statistic obtained through a large number of samples from a population.

nodes.label: Representativeness in data collection
nodes.title: Ensuring that the sample data accurately reflects the characteristics of the larger population to avoid biased results.

nodes.label: Measures of center in data
nodes.title: Statistics that describe the central tendency of a dataset, such as mean, median, and mode.

nodes.label: Variability in data
nodes.title: The extent to which data points in a dataset differ from each other, often measured by range, standard deviation, or interquartile range.

nodes.label: Correlation coefficient
nodes.title: A numerical measure that indicates the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables.

nodes.label: Outliers in data
nodes.title: Data points that significantly differ from the rest of the dataset, potentially affecting the overall analysis and conclusions.

nodes.label: Sampling variability
nodes.title: The natural variation in sample statistics that occurs when different samples are taken from the same population.

To find the perpendicular distance from a point to a line, one must first understand the equation of the line, as this is necessary for calculating the distance accurately.
Understanding differentiation from first principles provides the foundational knowledge required to apply differentiation rules effectively.
Knowledge of basic differentiation rules is necessary to understand and apply the more complex product, quotient, and chain rules in calculus.
To differentiate inverse trigonometric functions, one must first understand the differentiation of standard trigonometric functions, as these concepts are closely related.
Understanding how to differentiate exponential functions is essential for differentiating logarithmic functions, as logarithms are the inverses of exponentials.
Understanding probability requires first listing all possible outcomes of an experiment to define the sample space and calculate probabilities.
Calculating probabilities for equally likely outcomes in simple random processes builds on the foundational understanding of probability concepts.
Advanced probability rules such as AND/OR, mutually exclusive events, and expected value calculations require prior understanding of outcomes in simple random processes.
Solving problems involving Bernoulli trials and independent events depends on knowledge of probability rules including multiplication and conditional probability.
Before data can be represented graphically or numerically, students must learn how to find, collect, and organise data appropriately.
Drawing conclusions and interpreting data requires prior ability to represent data graphically and numerically to understand its distribution and relationships.
Understanding populations, samples, and data types builds on the ability to find and collect data and is essential for statistical reasoning and evaluating data quality.
